segment.source: Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) offers a simple command line interface.
segment.target: Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) offers a simple command line interface.

segment.source: The full complexity of WPR is embedded in the recording profiles.
segment.target: The full complexity of WPR is embedded in the recording profiles.

segment.source: WPR requires Windows 7 or later version operating system.
segment.target: WPR requires Windows 7 or later version operating system.

segment.source: The following sections describe the command-line options:
segment.target: The following sections describe the command-line options:

segment.source: If you start WPR from the command line while another application is recording (such as Xperf or an application that uses NT Kernel Logger, such as logman or PerfTrace), WPR fails to start recording and returns the following error:
segment.target: If you start WPR from the command line while another application is recording (such as Xperf or an application that uses NT Kernel Logger, such as logman or PerfTrace), WPR fails to start recording and returns the following error:

segment.source: In this case, you must cancel the other recording before you can start a new recording by using WPR.
segment.target: In this case, you must cancel the other recording before you can start a new recording by using WPR.

segment.source: Use this option to list the WPR profiles that the recording uses.
segment.target: Use this option to list the WPR profiles that the recording uses.

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: To see built-in profiles, omit the argument.
segment.target: To see built-in profiles, omit the argument.

segment.source: To list the profiles that are defined in a profile definition file, specify the path and name of that file.
segment.target: To list the profiles that are defined in a profile definition file, specify the path and name of that file.

segment.source: Use this option to start a recording by using one or more profiles.
segment.target: Use this option to start a recording by using one or more profiles.

source.pc: path to which the trace files are saved
number of iterations for OnOff tracing

target.pc: path to which the trace files are saved
number of iterations for OnOff tracing

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: Specifies either a built-in profile or the path to a user-defined profile.
segment.target: Specifies either a built-in profile or the path to a user-defined profile.

segment.source: You can specify up to 64 profiles on a single command line.
segment.target: You can specify up to 64 profiles on a single command line.

segment.source: Each profile is specified in the following way:
segment.target: Each profile is specified in the following way:

segment.source: Each profile can define either light or verbose versions, or both versions.
segment.target: Each profile can define either light or verbose versions, or both versions.

segment.source: If neither option is specified, the verbose version is used unless the profile includes only a light version.
segment.target: If neither option is specified, the verbose version is used unless the profile includes only a light version.

segment.source: For proper syntax, see the preceding code sample for profile or profilen.
segment.target: For proper syntax, see the preceding code sample for profile or profilen.

segment.source: Specifies that recording is done in file mode.
segment.target: Specifies that recording is done in file mode.

segment.source: By using this option, the data is recorded to an unbounded file, which can grow in size until it fills the disk.
segment.target: By using this option, the data is recorded to an unbounded file, which can grow in size until it fills the disk.

segment.source: Path to which the trace files are saved.
segment.target: Path to which the trace files are saved.

segment.source: Specifies one of the on/off transition types.
segment.target: Specifies one of the on/off transition types.

segment.source: These are: Boot, FastStartup, Shutdown, RebootCycle, Standby, or Hibernate.
segment.target: These are: Boot, FastStartup, Shutdown, RebootCycle, Standby, or Hibernate.

segment.source: Sets the number of iterations for OnOff recording.
segment.target: Sets the number of iterations for OnOff recording.

segment.source: By default, the settings from the built-in or custom profile file are used by default.
segment.target: By default, the settings from the built-in or custom profile file are used by default.

segment.source: Use this option to stop the current recording and save it to the file that is specified by the argument.
segment.target: Use this option to stop the current recording and save it to the file that is specified by the argument.

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: Specifies the event trace log (ETL) file to which WPR saves the recording.
segment.target: Specifies the event trace log (ETL) file to which WPR saves the recording.

segment.source: Although this argument is optional, we recommended that you use it.
segment.target: Although this argument is optional, we recommended that you use it.

segment.source: Use this option to cancel the current recording without saving the recorded data.
segment.target: Use this option to cancel the current recording without saving the recorded data.

segment.source: If no instance is currently active, an error is returned.
segment.target: If no instance is currently active, an error is returned.

segment.source: Use this option to display status information about the current WPR recording.
segment.target: Use this option to display status information about the current WPR recording.

segment.source: If no recording is currently active, a message displays that WPR is not recording.
segment.target: If no recording is currently active, a message displays that WPR is not recording.

segment.source: If a recording is currently active and no arguments are used, the following status information displays:
segment.target: If a recording is currently active and no arguments are used, the following status information displays:

segment.source: If you supply arguments together with the –status option, the information listed above displays together with data that is specific to that option.
segment.target: If you supply arguments together with the –status option, the information listed above displays together with data that is specific to that option.

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: This argument lists each profile that is being used in the current WPR recording.
segment.target: This argument lists each profile that is being used in the current WPR recording.

segment.source: If buffers have been lost, those buffers are listed.
segment.target: If buffers have been lost, those buffers are listed.

segment.source: Collector Name : NT Kernel Logger Buffer Size (KB) : 1024 Events Lost : 0 System Keywords CSwitch ProcessThread SampledProfile System Stacks CSwitch SampledProfile
segment.target: Collector Name : NT Kernel Logger Buffer Size (KB) : 1024 Events Lost : 0 System Keywords CSwitch ProcessThread SampledProfile System Stacks CSwitch SampledProfile

segment.source: Collector Name : WPR_initiated_WPR Event Collector Buffer Size (KB) : 1024 Events Lost : 0 Providers Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Core: 0x1000000000000: 0x04 Microsoft-Windows-Win32k: 0x1000000402000: 0xff : Stack CaptureState Providers on Save Microsoft-Windows-Win32k: 0x80000: 0xff
segment.target: Collector Name : WPR_initiated_WPR Event Collector Buffer Size (KB) : 1024 Events Lost : 0 Providers Microsoft-Windows-Shell-Core: 0x1000000000000: 0x04 Microsoft-Windows-Win32k: 0x1000000402000: 0xff : Stack CaptureState Providers on Save Microsoft-Windows-Win32k: 0x80000: 0xff

segment.source: Lists additional information about each collector.
segment.target: Lists additional information about each collector.

segment.source: Use this option to display detailed information about a profile or set of profiles.
segment.target: Use this option to display detailed information about a profile or set of profiles.

segment.source: To specify multiple profiles, use the following syntax where n refers to the name of each profile.
segment.target: To specify multiple profiles, use the following syntax where n refers to the name of each profile.

segment.source: Use this option to display detailed information about providers.
segment.target: Use this option to display detailed information about providers.

segment.source: Providers refer to the Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) components that expose events to Windows Performance Recorder (WPR).
segment.target: Providers refer to the Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) components that expose events to Windows Performance Recorder (WPR).

segment.source: To display information about providers, use the following syntax where ** refers to all installed/known and registered providers.
segment.target: To display information about providers, use the following syntax where ** refers to all installed/known and registered providers.

segment.source: Use this option to turn Disable Paging Executive settings On or Off.
segment.target: Use this option to turn Disable Paging Executive settings On or Off.

segment.source: To correctly capture event stacks on 64-bit systems that are running Windows 7, disablepagingexecutive should be set to On, and the system must be rebooted before you start performance recording.
segment.target: To correctly capture event stacks on 64-bit systems that are running Windows 7, disablepagingexecutive should be set to On, and the system must be rebooted before you start performance recording.

segment.source: For 32-bit systems that are running Windows 7 and for all systems that are running Windows 8 or higher, you can operate performance recording without setting disablepagingexecutive to On.
segment.target: For 32-bit systems that are running Windows 7 and for all systems that are running Windows 8 or higher, you can operate performance recording without setting disablepagingexecutive to On.

segment.source: Use this option to append and configure debug logging to the event log.
segment.target: Use this option to append and configure debug logging to the event log.

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: Enables debug logging to the event log.
segment.target: Enables debug logging to the event log.

segment.source: Disables debug logging to the event log.
segment.target: Disables debug logging to the event log.

segment.source: Uninstalls the WPR debug logging provider manifest from the system.
segment.target: Uninstalls the WPR debug logging provider manifest from the system.

segment.source: Use this option to purge the managed symbols cache.
segment.target: Use this option to purge the managed symbols cache.

segment.source: Use this option to display on-line help in the Command Prompt window.
segment.target: Use this option to display on-line help in the Command Prompt window.

segment.source: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.
segment.target: The following table describes the available arguments that you can apply to this option.

segment.source: Each time that WPR saves a trace that was captured when managed applications were running on the system, WPR saves managed symbols next to the trace file.
segment.target: Each time that WPR saves a trace that was captured when managed applications were running on the system, WPR saves managed symbols next to the trace file.

segment.source: This feature enables performance analysis of managed applications.
segment.target: This feature enables performance analysis of managed applications.

segment.source: Generating managed symbols is a resource- and time-consuming operation.
segment.target: Generating managed symbols is a resource- and time-consuming operation.

segment.source: WPR automatically creates a managed symbol cache to expedite the generation of managed symbols.
segment.target: WPR automatically creates a managed symbol cache to expedite the generation of managed symbols.

segment.source: When WPR needs managed symbols, it first checks this cache and uses any available and appropriate symbols instead of regenerating them.
segment.target: When WPR needs managed symbols, it first checks this cache and uses any available and appropriate symbols instead of regenerating them.

segment.source: The default managed symbol cache location is C:ProgramDataWindowsPerformanceRecorderNGenPdbsCache.
segment.target: The default managed symbol cache location is C:ProgramDataWindowsPerformanceRecorderNGenPdbsCache.
